Football firsts two games away from final after fourth round success

The men's football firsts find themselves two games away from the BUCS Cup final after beating Huddersfield firsts 3-2, despite being 1-0 down at the break (Thumbnail credit Image: Sam Newsome)

Rugby seconds humbled by impressive Hull

The men's rugby seconds came up against an unbeaten Hull firsts today and paid the price, losing 52-5 (Thumbnail credit Image: Sam Newsome)

Women's lacrosse defeated by one point

York's women's lacrosse players were on the wrong-end of a close 9-8 scoreline against Leeds firsts today (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Men's badminton reproduce winning formula

The men's badminton team recent good form continued as they dispatched Newcastle University 6-2 to revenge defeat earlier in the season (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

York men squash Northumbria in the cup

With the 4th Round of the FA Cup taking place this weekend, York men's squash team got into the swing of things early with a 3-2 victory over league-leaders Northumbria University (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Derwent take the points against Halifax

A second-half Xander Brinkworth strike allowed Derwent to beat Halifax 1-0 this morning as College Football returned to York (Thumbnail credit Derwent's Dom Henney out-jumps Halifax's Gio Palides. Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Dheir breaks Langwith hearts with winner

A late Nick Dheir goal gave Sam Lewis' Goodricke a 1-0 victory over a resilient Langwith (Thumbnail credit Langwith on a rare foray forward. Image: Aaste Haukvik Traen)

Concerted Alcuin effort defeats James

Alcuin kicked off their term of College Football with a hard-fought 3-2 win over rivals James. (Thumbnail credit James do their utmost to prevent Alcuin. Image: Aaste Haukvik Traen)

Taylor inspirational as Vanbrugh hit Wentworth for five

College Football returned today with Phil Taylor inspiring his Vanbrugh side to a 5-0 victory over Wentworth. (Thumbnail credit Phil Taylor, sporting Vanbrugh's new Crystal Palace-esque kit, attempts to evade the attention of the Wentworth defence. Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

York St. John Sabbatical Officer voices disappointment over Varsity shake-up

York St. John's Vice-President for Student Activities, Jason Chappelow, has voiced his disappointment that Varsity will now be contested between Hull and York and will no longer be between York's intra-city rivals (Thumbnail credit Image: Peter Iveson)

Monday Night Lights: Ambrozejczyk on American Sport

Everybody's favourite York-based journalist who focuses on American Sport is back, as David Ambrozejczyk delivers another Monday Night Lights (Thumbnail credit &quot;Karma is a b****&quot; - wise words from LeBron James, a well renowned philosopher. Image: Keith Allison via Flickr Creative Commons)

Netball seconds lose out in Carnegie clash

The netball seconds faced Leeds Metropolitan Carnegie in a top-of-the-table clash yesterday, unfortunately it was the away side who claimed the points winning 37-29 on the day. (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

Men's badminton hammer bottom side Leeds

The men's badminton firsts kicked off the new term successfully as they dispatched the University of Leeds 6-2 to allay relegation fears (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

The future of Varsity up in the air as Hull replace neighbours York St. John

Annual Varsity sports tournament is set for a major overhaul as the University of Hull will replace close neighbours York St. John in a bid to create a more worthwhile and competitive tournament (Thumbnail credit Billy Walsh in action in last year's Varsity hockey match. This year will see York's finest do battle with the University of Hull instead of local rivals York St John university. Photo credit: Peter Iveson)

2011 for York Sport: New year, new York?

Deputy Sports Editors Sam Morgan and George Bouras assess how last term went for seven of York's biggest teams and ask what they need to do this term in order to push on (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: George Lowther)

Controversial red card for York in a heated encounter fails to prevent winning start to year

York's rugby firsts closed out an eventful match on the 22 Acres to earn a place in the next round of the cup. In a match that saw two yellow cards and one red for the home team, York have good reason to be pleased with their against the odds 10-7 victory (Thumbnail credit Another Liverpool attack is thwarted by a resilient York defence. York's 10-7 victory is a good start to the year. Photo credit: Peter Iveson)

Local side Yopen taste victory in Ultimate tournament

Local side Yopen managed to claim glory in a competitive and enjoyable Ultimate tournament hosted at the University last Saturday (Thumbnail credit Yopen secured the title with a victory over 'Danger! High Voltage' in the final of last Saturday's tournament. Photo credit: Peter Iveson)

Hull can only improve Varsity for York students

Sam Asfahani's decision to replace York St. John with the University of Hull should be applauded for re-invigorating a competition that has long since gone from being a competitive event, to an annual walk in the park for York (Thumbnail credit Phil Taylor celebrates against Hull, the uni who have replaced St. John. Photo credit: Peter Iveson)

The Mixer

The footballing world has reached its silly season. Big name signings are being "spotted" at train stations up and down the country, anonymous youngsters are being touted as wonderkids and, due to incessant phone calls, the wife of Robbie Keane's agent hasn't been able to sleep for weeks (Thumbnail credit It's a managerial merry-go-round...do you get it? Photo credit: practicalowl)

Paul Collingwood's greatest hits

Richard Smith gets all weepy and remembers the highs of Paul Collingwood's England career (Thumbnail credit One of the world's most powerful men, pictured here meeting David Cameron. Image: The Prime Minister's Office via Flickr Creative Commons)

Lewis fulfills potential with memorable win

Adrian Lewis clinched the 2011 Ladbrokes.com World Darts Championship on Monday, Sam Morgan reviews the action (Thumbnail credit Adrian Lewis, the 2011 Ladbrokes.com World Darts Championships winner. Image: sachab via Flickr Creative Commons)

Will Formula One's rule changes affect the drama?

Luke Gardener assesses whether Formula One's new rule changes, coming in next season, will impinge on the excitement of the sport (Thumbnail credit Will the rule changes allow Vettel to remain number one next year? Image: Silverstone Circuits Limited via Flickr Creative Commons)

Sacking Sam Allardyce was the right decision

Peter Iveson makes a hotly anticipated return to writing with his assessment of why sacking Sam Allardyce was the right thing to do (Thumbnail credit Image: michael.kjaer via Flickr Creative Commons)

The Ashes haven't been won yet

Richard Smith, raised on a diet of English losses, dons his cynical hat to argue that Australia are by no means out of the Ashes (Thumbnail credit Ricky Ponting, very much under pressure, is plotting a way back into the series for his side. Image: nznationalparty via Flickr Creative Commons)

Men's badminton seconds secure first win of season

The men's badminton seconds picked up their first win of the season today, overcoming Sheffield Hallam seconds 5-3 (Thumbnail credit Image: Justyn Hardcastle)

The Ashes: some memorable moments

With England one win away from retaining the little urn, Sarah Robinson reflects on some of the Ashes' most memorable moments (Thumbnail credit Brad Haddin, a victim of karma. Image: &lt;DXR&gt; via Flickr Creative Commons)

Playing the right way

Sean Cole argues that the beautiful game's current obsession with 'sexy football' ignores the art of winning games and underestimates the less aesthetically pleasing matches (Thumbnail credit Arsene Wenger; stylish, but the trophy cabinet has been bare of late. Image: Ronnie Macdonald via Flickr Creative Commons)

Monday Night Lights: Ambrozejczyk on American Sport

David Ambrozejczyk delivers the perfect early Christmas present with the sixth installment of his American Sports Blog. (Thumbnail credit The 2010 Heisman Trophy winner, Cam Newton. Image: Chris Pusateri Photography via Flickr Creative Commons)

What is wrong with English football?

Bradley Wood investigates England's failed 2018 World Cup bid and questions whether there is a larger problem affecting the English game. (Thumbnail credit Even David Cameron couldn't persuade Sepp Blatter and his cronies to back England's bid: Image: The Prime Minister's Office via Flickr Creative Commons)

Do Premier League managers have a chance?

Luke Gardener discusses the sacking of ex-Newcastle manager Chris Hughton and explores its meaning in the wider context of the game. (Thumbnail credit The recently departed Chris Hughton, unfairly dismissed by Newcastle owner Mike Ashley. Image: blenky64 via Flickr Creative Commons)
